What are the greatest contributions Japan has made to the world? I have completed thirty-eight years here in the Kansai (Kyoto-Osaka-Kobe) area. Offhand, I would say that the country is making its greatest contribution right now, in its example of a relatively peaceful, prosperous, harmonious, egalitarian society essentially free of religion. I can imagine no greater gift to the world. This is a huge topic difficult to summarize in just a few words, but I will do my best. Needless to say, Japan today is far from being a perfect society. Women are not treated fairly, drug use is emerging as a concern, and so on. Immanuel Kant made a remark to the effect that nothing straight has ever been crafted from the crooked timber of human nature, and that is of course true. Nevertheless, in my opinion Japan has done well recently, however much remains to be achieved. Yes, there are traces of religion here. To judge by what I have seen, a great deal, I think it is fair to put it that way. But Japanese society today is, first and foremost, irrefutable proof that religion is not necessary to human life. Those countries that attempt to establish this or that religion as the basis of society are thoroughly mistaken, and their miserable lack of success is additional proof, if any were needed. It is also an argument for an assumption that struck me as odd when I first encountered it. In the United States, the idea appears to be that the elite, educational and financial, deserves special attention, since it has the power to save society in general. Here in Japan, the idea is that the bottom of society deserves special attention, since it must not be allowed to sink too low. Recently I have come to the conclusion that the former assumption is fantasy, and the latter sound. It is also an argument for group spirit, and for dedication to one’s work as opposed to maximum personal gain. An English girlfriend remarked to me decades ago, “Here [in Japan], everybody simply does his best.” There are remarkably few exceptions. It is an argument for relative income equality, too, which of course accords with group spirit. The United States is making a horrific mistake, unfortunately one of many, in allowing, indeed aggressively promoting, runaway inequality. And it is an argument for doing all it takes to care for the children, however burdensome a task that proves to be, and not merely giving lip service to the concept in the abstract. The children I see here are invariably happy, firmly guided, and well-protected. The tiger-mama who insists on the best education possible for her children is no myth. Much of the success of Japanese society today stems from its relatively pervasive, though far from complete, uniformity, and consequent unity of spirit. You might draw the conclusion that the world’s peoples ought to segregate themselves and trade across the fences, as it were, but that is obviously both impractical and wrong-headed. The right conclusion, I think, is this: The world’s peoples must look past superficial factors like coloration, language, and local culture and peculiarities in general, and learn to achieve unity of spirit in view of their deep-set common humanity. It won’t be easy. It will be worth it.

Q. What are the greatest contributions Japan has made to the world? A. 5 Japanese innovations that changed the world Few places have done more than Japan to define today’s technological landscape. The laptops we all work from? Toshiba was the first to produce them for a mass market. The emoji you used in your last email? Also a Japanese invention. In fact, according to a Forbes analysis, Japan is home to almost 10% of the world’s most innovative companies. And yet Japan’s creative prowess is all too often overlooked, with most people instead focusing on places like Silicon Valley or Tel Aviv. As these five innovations show, that’s a mistake – Japan has given the world far more than karaoke, Pokémon and instant ramen noodles. Bullet train (1964)  Before the Hikari No. 1 was launched in October 1964, travelling by train between Tokyo and Osaka – Japan’s two largest cities – would take the best part of a working day. But with a top speed of 210 kph, the world’s first bullet train reduced the journey to 4 hours. Today, thanks to further technological developments, the trip takes just over 2 hours, soon to be reduced to around an hour.  Pocket calculator (1970) You’re out for dinner with a group of friends and the bill arrives. What’s the first thing you do? Grab your smartphone and head for the calculator app. This handy little tool has its origins in a Japanese invention: the pocket calculator.  The Sharp QT-8B You’d have needed enormous pockets to actually carry one around with you – the first models were instead designed to keep on your desk – but it was probably easier than lugging an abacus to the restaurant. Walkman (1979) Think the iPod revolutionized the music industry? Wrong. When Apple’s product hit the market in 2001, the revolution was already well under way, thanks to a Japanese invention that came decades earlier: Sony’s Walkman. Before the Walkman, the only way to listen to music on the go was by using a portable radio. The idea that you could pick your own tunes and listen to them everywhere would transform the music industry. “Mobility – the concept that you could take music with you – was huge,” Americus Reed of Wharton told AdWeek.  A 1980s Sony Walkman advert Blue LED light (early 1990s) In the early 1990s, three Japanese scientists – Isamu Akasaki, Hiroshi Amano and Shuji Nakamura – set off a lighting revolution when they managed to produce blue LED light from their semi-conductors. The discovery paved the way for energy-efficient TV, mobile and computer screens, and power-saving lightbulbs. It has been described as having the potential to revolutionize the 21st century, and the three scientists were awarded the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics.  Nobel physics laureates 2014 Professor Shuji Nakamura, Professor Isamu Akasaki and Professor Hiroshi Amano Image: REUTERS/Janerik Henriksson Android robots (2003) Once limited to the realm of science fiction, androids – robots that look, speak and act like humans – are now very much a reality, thanks to Japanese inventors. In 2003, researchers from The Intelligent Robotics Lab at Osaka University unveiled the DER 01, the first all-talking, blinking and breathing, human-like robot. These robots are already transforming the country. In the summer of 2015, a hotel with an almost entirely robot personnel opened in Nagasaki. Two years earlier, Kirobo became the world’s first robot astronaut to speak in space.  10 Japanese inventions that changed the world (according to Chinese media)  Michelle Lynn Dinh Nov 27, 2013Japan has invented some pretty cool things; Mario, the Nissan Skyline, and PlayStation to name a few. Sure, sexy cars and even sexier game systems are great, but what would you choose as the truly exceptional Japanese inventions that influenced the world? Chinese media site, Xinhua Net News, weighed in on this question, giving us their top 10 list of most influential inventions from Japan. 10) DVDs  Image: Wikipedia Growing up, my family actually had a laser disc player and a decent collection of nearly 12-inch wide discs. When the whole family gathered to watch a movie, it was a sure thing that it would be interrupted halfway through and my sisters and I would have to fight over who had to flip the disc to continue on with the film. DVDs changed everything, providing enough capacity to fit an entire movie and then some. Blu-Rays have now nudged their way into the market, but it was the invention of the DVD back in 1995 that changed the way we store information and view movies at home. 9) Video Camera  Image: Wikipedia Where would America’s Funniest Home Videos be without the invention of the video camera? Thanks for the hours of entertainment, Japan, and for making some of life’s most embarrassing moments live on forever. 8) Digital Camera  Image: Wikipedia Sony came out with the first digital camera in 1981, and from that moment on, any and all seemingly precious memories were required to be documented for future embarrassment of one’s child. 7) Walkman  Image: Wikipedia That’s right, 1979 was the year of the Walkman, Sony’s game changing mobile music listening device. It was the iPod of the 80s and turned music into a private listening experience. 6) CD  Image: Wikipedia (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Compact_disc.svg) Mixtapes are so 1987, it was all about the mixCD once they became widely available in the 1990s. It was Sony that first invented the CD, forever changing the way we listened to music. And although the use of CDs is on a steady decline in the digital age, that mixCD from 2002 I found in my closet will always have a place in my heart. 5) Karaoke  Image: Wikipedia You have Japan to thank for obnoxious drunks screaming “Living on a Prayer” at the top of their lungs. Yep, Karaoke is a Japanese invention, incorporating the word kara, or “empty,” and oke, a shortened version of “orchestra.” 4) Video Tape Recorder (VTR)  Image: Wikipedia Ah, the days when you’d record your favorite shows on a VHS tape and store them with sticky white labels declaring the titles of your pirated merch. The introduction of Sony’s Betamax in 1975 made it all possible. Now we’re on to DVDs and even Blu-Rays, but VTRs were all the rage in the 80s and in use up until the early 2000s. 3) Electronic Calculators  Image: Wikipedia Invented by Casio in 1957, the electronic calculator made quick addition possible and made math class infinitely easier (and in some cases less necessary). Once out of school, you never had to do long division on a piece of paper if you didn’t want to and you certainly didn’t have to memorize your times tables (curse you, sevens!). 2) Instant Ramen  Image: Wikipedia Who hasn’t had instant ramen at least once in their life? The college staple is actually a Japanese native, invented in cup form by Nissin Foods in 1971. Instant ramen comes in at number two on the list, second only to… 1) Electric Rice Cooker  Image: Panasonic What’s easier than cooking rice? In modern times, probably nothing thanks to the invention of the electric rice cooker in 1940 by Mitsubishi Electric. But before this awesome Japanese invention was born, skilled cooks would have to steam the precious staple on a stove (or in many cases a fire), hoping the grains didn’t burn or stick to the pot. So thanks for the perfectly cooked rice, Japan. Our sushi, donburi and curry applaud you. Source: Xinhua

Well, I could say Aibo, the Sony robotic puppy; anime robot girls; more Ignoble Prize winners than anyone else (“banana peels really ARE slippery”); natto; SMAP; improvised flying suicide weapons and so on. But I want to see if I can come up with some more lasting, scientific ones. You know like electricity, Morse Code, Teflon, and velcro. One I know of is amazing - quantum tunnel diodes, by Nobel laureate Leo Esaki, which gives us advanced modern LEDs and solar power cells. The blue laser diode which gives us - hey, Blue Ray discs (sort of dated in the Netflix era) but massive throughput in optical cables - by Shuji Nakamura. “Umami” - the great taste sensation that gave birth to Ajinomoto, one of Japan’s food industry global champions; discovery of the amazing ability by living cells to do housecleaning, aka autophagy, by another Nobel laureate, Yoshinori Ohsumi. Stem-cells. Oh, and let’s not forget, the Steven Jobs of Japan, namely the late and great Akio Morita, co-founder of SONY. He imagined and invented NOT ONLY the first portable earphone music player, the WalkMan, but also the first ever digital camera, the MAVICA. I hope in Heaven he and Steve kept up their courteous rivalry. In engineering, composite materials, miniature electronic devices, there are dozens if not hundreds more. The stuff of Shinkansen bullet trains. The Prius. But let’s not forget sushi, sumo (and chanko-nabe), aikido, bunraku puppetry, the gorgeous and sexy Awa-odori dance from Tokushima, the geisha culture, and the otaku culture. Capsule hotels and love hotels. Cube-shape furo-bathtubs. Cheers.

I believe the greatest contribution Japan has made is not any technological innovation or product. Their greatest contribution is showing the world that a society can be organized in such a way that things work reasonably well. The place is clean, safe, the trains and busses run on time, the people are reasonably polite, the infrastructure is constantly being updated, the medical system is widely and fairly cheaply available. I could go on, but you get the point. Yes, yes there are cultural, historical, and geographic factors that make the “Japanese way” peculiar and not easily transferable to other countries. Not perfect by any means, and no utopia, nevertheless, Japan does show the world alternative possibilities of living.

response.answer_text: Japan has offered so much to our modern world that there's a Wikipedia page for it. But besides all those wonderful contributions, my pick would be this:  Puella Magi Madoka Magica. I know you're probably thinking “Seriously?” but there's a story behind I put this here. This was recommended to me by a senior resident in Emergency medicine when I was working/studying there as an exchange student. I took one look at it and thought “WTF is this?” but reserved my comments since I had a lot of respect for the man. Three years passed before I finally watched it. Three years later and I'm still reeling. No words can truly express how I feel about this work of art. Miyazaki is great and all but this… this took all my expectations, pulverised them and served them back to me as pressed juice. My attitude towards books, movies and any other form of storytelling hasn't been the same ever since. That's why, to me, this is the greatest thing that has come out of Japan.

There are too many to choose from, but as a kid I would have answered:  It’s a childhood classic, everyone loves this movie. And of course:  Such a great game, and the theme song is so iconic. And lastly, I would go for:  Not just for the cars they make that get billions of people from A to B everyday, but because their philosophies have changed the way the modern manufacturing industry operates. Toyota pioneered the concept of Lean Manufacturing (aka the Toyota Production System) in the 1950’s, a concept that aims to minimise waste and maximise output. This not only allowed Toyota to catch up to Ford but overtake it in quality, cost and delivery. Today, nearly all manufacturing industries, not just automotive, adopt aspects of the Toyota Production System to make their products. Everything we use is made with some Lean Manufacturing practices in the production process. And this for me is Japan’s biggest contribution to the modern world.
